03_In-Grid/Serving In-grid/media/Serving.title: Serving In-grid workshop day
Serving In-grid workshop day 2

03_In-Grid/Serving In-grid/Serving In-gr.title: Serving In-grid
03_In-Grid/Serving In-grid/Serving In-gr.description:
These are the workshops that I organised with In-grid members and reflect on in the 06.03.02.00_Configure-ability_In-Workshops entries. In these workshops we set up our VPS server with Servus, as an experimental server for us to test and explore some different network infrastructure projects. In the workshop we made space for us to figure out how we wanted to imagine and enact our infrastructure as we made it. Check out the:
Serving In-grid Workshop slides I presented
Workshop Pad we used
Femfester Manifesto we wrote.

03_In-Grid/03_In-Grid.html.title: 03_In-Grid
03_In-Grid/03_In-Grid.html.description:
These entries share the practice I took on as part of In-grid collective that I reflect on more in the 06_In-Configure-Ability section of this research. These entries share a variety of practices from some coded visuals, to workshops, skill shares, docs and focus groups. These aim to make room to share how these inquiries and actions have manifested my practice of critical access within an intersectional community.In this section I share:
In-fra Processing focus group
In-Docs
Serving In-grid workshop

04_Cozy-Cloud/Cozy_Night+Day/Cozy_Night_.title: Cozy_Night_and_Day
04_Cozy-Cloud/Cozy_Night+Day/Cozy_Night_.description:
This is the current website theme for the 04_Cozy-Cloud, and works with Bludit CMS. It is made to have be very light weight and network accessible, as it also utilises tags/code to activate Screen Readers (shared below). This website so far documents the work of the Cozy-Cloud by giving lightweight introductions to each work. It also aims to be a step towards making more room within this infrastructure for easier collaborations and exchanges as it can have multiple users and work in the web interface. Check out the:
Downloadable Theme
Instructions on how to run it Formatting your html or php so it uses these tags will enable screen readers to easily pick up on the content in a page.<article> <h2 class="mb2"> page title </h2> <p> by <span class="author">author</span> on <time class="dateline">date</time> </p> <div class="cover"><img src="./cover.img" alt="a cute cover image"/>"></div> <div> <p> Content </p> </div> </article>

04_Cozy-Cloud/Cozy-Intentions/Cozy-Inten.title: Cozy-Intentions
04_Cozy-Cloud/Cozy-Intentions/Cozy-Inten.description:
This page brings together cozy intentions for the cozy-cloud crip (disability justice) space. This is to give an understanding of how * why this crip centred platform came to be and to share some of the desires we have when making an affirmative digital space that centres disabled people.These intentions appear as image and alt text pairs, each defining its own thread to be followed, weaving together a story or figuring of the cozy-cloud. In a classic crip move, they entangle together the affective feelings of our mind body and their knowledges, within an understanding of political relational modelling to imagine new ways to transform our social * technical infrastructures. Simply put these intentions mean to affirm what we feel as disabled people in both our bodies and minds, and to enable those knowledges at the centre of transforming digital communication networks and systems like social media platforms. maybe something about enviro x materialThese intentions ask: If we as disabled neurodiverse chronically ill people are able to transform digital spaces and communities and their material infrastructure (+ the environmental effects they have) from a space of crip care and time, what could that look like and feel like?If you are a member of the cozy-cloud platform and want to add to or tweak these intentions and you have not had the opportunity yet please message COZY for the etherpad they are edited on.
Furry text saying "Let's Get Cozy", welcomes you to get cozy! This is an enthusiastic and loving message reminding you to get cozy in what ever way you are able to.Many times (not always) when we can't get cozy,our experience it is telling us that something might be wrong systemically. This text asks us to think, what would enable me to get cozy? What relations would have to change for us to actually be cozy? By trying to get cozy we start to make these transformations, so settle in and lets get cozy.
A cloud sits unsure on a day with mixed weather. It feels sensitive to the gusts and gales of bigger clouds and so searches for a sheltered valley to get cozy and come back to earth. It asks us to think about how we feel in the cloud. When we are using cloud enabled devices, like streaming, cloud drives or social platforms do we feel a connection to what it is we are doing? What would it feel like to ground and get cozy with our digital infrastructures.
The cozy-cloud sits within a ring of furry and cozy text saying "Less Cloud - More Cozy". It feels warmth in knowing its energies are conserved for doing cozy things and not being a part of deadly storms elsewhere. It asks us to think about less dispersion of our digital selves into a commercial cloud that displaces the harms of digital infrastructures out of sight. How can we settle in, keep ourselves close and feel out how cozy our clouds could be?
Slightly clumsy but cute furry text says "Clouds are finite :( Coziness can be infinite!". It sits slightly slumped to one side, exhausted with keeping up with the continuous expansion. It helps us to reflect on the limitations of computing and cloud infrastructures, the consumption of fossil fuels, rare minerals and people's labour to try to maintain the unmaintainable infinite growth. What if we centre our clouds on other infinities of care, compassion and coziness? What would infrastructures feel like and be able of through these gentler modes?
A map of arpnet, an early computer network produced by the us gov/army is transformed into a cozy-constellation. This transformation resembles the way digital networks have a history of control of space (both physical and virtual) through force and how we have to transform them with care and coziness.It asks us how we could imagine networks away from these histories of mapping, taxonomy and creating specific ways of knowing/doing? Instead can we imagine it as a relation of gravitates to be felt but unknowable?
A png of a cloud with transparent background so that it looks like it is comfortable and confident wherever it is displayed. The cloud looks so light and pretty floating on the page, but still on the edge of creating a little drizzle. The image itself is also on a free license so is free like a cloud!It reminds us what a cloud looks like and what it is able of. The computational infrastructures that make up the commercial cloud could never be so light nor caring to our ecology nor our body/minds. What metaphors or analogies would you give the cloud? How would you transform them through putting this digital infrastructure in your own terms.

headers.heading: Clouds are finite :( Coziness can be infinite
Transform networks of control 2 constellations of care

04_Cozy-Cloud/Cozy-ish/Cozy-ish.html.title: Cozy-ish
04_Cozy-Cloud/Cozy-ish/Cozy-ish.html.description:
Cozy-ish is the first theme for the Cozy-Cloud blog which ran with a Pico CMS. This theme was initially made to hold the Cozy-Intentions as well as some docs for the early setup. It is made to be an accessible, minimal and Cozy aesthetic to host these intentions and information. It is an adapted version of Winnie Soon's Soonish and adds a few minor edits to make it a lil more cozy.Check out the:
Cozy-ish_theme.zip (download theme)

04_Cozy-Cloud/En-crip-ing_time/En-crip-i.title: En-crip-ing_time
04_Cozy-Cloud/En-crip-ing_time/En-crip-i.description:
This is a crip infrastructure I made in collaboration with Mariana Marangoni that inquired how we could make room for crip time in network time, now and in the future. It also questions the intimacies and care needed to not only manifest, but maintain crip infrastructures like these. This work was presented at Mesh Festival, as well as an essay about it published with Brand-New-Life Journal.Check out the:
Crip infrastructure live
Published essay
Mesh festival talk info

04_Cozy-Cloud/Serving Cozy/media/Serving.title: Serving Cozy in touch

04_Cozy-Cloud/Serving Cozy/Serving Cozy..title: Serving Cozy
04_Cozy-Cloud/Serving Cozy/Serving Cozy..description: This is the installed Cozy-Cloud relaxation space and server that makes room for disabled bodies to be in proximity to network infrastructure and for them to make their own knowing and expertise of them through multi-sensory and media approaches. This server is hosted using a VPN so that it can move around and bring with it this relaxation space to imagine crip networks infrastructures from. To make this cozy relaxation space this server brings with it cozy cloud cushions, stickers and a Printable Easy Read Version of the Cozy-Intentions. This aims to offer up room around the Cozy-Cloud server, and outside of network space to emerge, and specifically from relaxing, dream full and cozy backgrounds and contexts.

04_Cozy-Cloud/04_Cozy-Cloud.html.title: 04_Cozy-Cloud
04_Cozy-Cloud/04_Cozy-Cloud.html.description:
The Cozy-Cloud is a crip centred server which makes room for a cripping of network infrastructures by bringing disabled bodies, politics and expertise in touch with these infrastructures. This servers initiation is discussed in much detail at 03.01_The_research_table, and gives shape to not only why this room is needed within both research and computing, but also the frictions I encountered in trying to make this sort of room between these sedimented norms.
I also go on to latter talk more closely about the work and collaborations I did with the Cozy-Cloud in the 07_A_Cozier_Configure-Able_Methods and the formation of some of the infrastructure, practices and collavorations it made space for.In this section I share:
Serving Cozy
Cozy-ish
Cozy-Intentions
En-crip-ing_time
Cozy_Night_and_Day

05_Research/05_Knowledge Bases.html.title: 05_Knowledge Bases
05_Research/05_Knowledge Bases.html.description:
This section highlights some of the knowledge base practice and research which is not that present on this research table but helped to bring it into being. This work is orienting that of how I collected, collated and held together this research through notes, short essays, annotated essays, chapters and media. To do this I worked with Obsidian as it made room for me to hold these many disparate things together. To do this here I share the workshop Making Sense with Obsidian that me and Batool Desouky organised for students on the Make Sense program at the Critical Media Lab, FNHW, Basel. This workshop aimed to share the practices Batool and I had emerged within Obsidian, but in a way that makes room for others to hack and emerge their own approach to researching. Check out the:
Workshop materials

Methods.html.title: Disobedient Action Research Methods
Methods.html.description: The indeterminate diagram above is representative of how this project's disobedient methodology disorients the standardized and prescribed methods of configuration. Every time you visit this page, and every time you click on the diagram, it creates a different composition of actions, sense makings and wiggling of room that my methodology entices. Visually it forms loops and cycles of different network diagram symbols and labels connected by lines and arrows. Each diagram also has a generated alt text of the syntax of the diagram which can be interpreted in a similarly playful way, and is attached to the <div> with the .mermaid class. Here are the mermaid docs to help decode diagrams. This code is an edit of another work/performance called Pad2Party that Sunni Liao and I made as part or RealBodies 2.1 with In-grid. The methodology for this project is a Disobedient Action Research Methodology. As the above texture and indeterminate diagram tries to highlight, this methodology disobediently refuses to be generalized or normalized into set terms of engagement. Instead this projects methodology aims to make wiggle room for bringing in the backgrounds of the bodyminds to be in touch with and shape the sociotechnical infrastructures and matters they are impacted by. To build up my projects Disobedient Action Research methodology I crip the methods of TiTIPi to ask what room can collective embodied inquiries make within infrastructuring. With this methodology disobediently being intimate with and building up collective expertise around what is and can be within reach socially and technically. In this Disobedient methodology I also aims to re-frame what actions can be taken within my research and how they can coalesce together and shape what is made known through action within the often hard and inflexible configurations of complex systems.The disobedience

index.html.title: Is It Configure-Able?
index.html.description: With my project I make room to inquire with collaborators if our infrastructures are Configure-Able. Informed by Queer theory, crip theory and critical access practices, this project works from the sites of friction within configurations to wiggle room into how these processes and relations can be shaped by the bodies they impact.Orienting with Sarah Ahmed's table (2006), I make room to question how the institutional norms of computing and academia keep the life affirming infrastructures we desire out of reach. With Ahmed and Helen Pritchard's concept of Wiggle Room (2022; 2014) I question how to make room to feel these pains and misfitting of the table, and in response wiggle and disorient these tables towards disabled bodies, futures and politics. With Alison Kafer (2013) and Aimi Hamraie (2017), I surface the ways they begin to not only validate the feelings and sense making of friction within relations, but also the making of friction from embodied expertise and through interdependence. In practice this workshop has taken up

Practice.html.title: Practice
Practice.html.description:
In this section I share the practice and inquiries I undertook to feel out my research. These different inquiries emerged through my Crip Disobedient Action Research Methods and are split into two sections. These aim to offer up both the foreground of the inquiries as well as the background they are in retreat from and contoured by.The first section covers my main inquiries and practice around my collaborative research into Configure-able Infrastructures. These inquiries take on workshops, focus groups, docs, speculative infrastructures and * * * * *.
Multi column
This section doesn't have a canvas as it is just one file. This shares in it the Configure-Able Infrastructures workshops I set up and ran with NEoN Digital.
This section shares the practice I undertook with members of In-grid collective. These range from focus groups, to accessible docs and workshops that orient critical access within intersectional collective practice. This section shares the practice I undertook when emerging the Cozy-Cloud as a crip and life affirmation centred server space. This collaboration made room for us to crip network practices and make room for disabled people to imagine the futures of digital infrastructures with them in. This section shares more of the background to the research, offering up my initial practice into AI and automation, as well as the research practices I emerged this project through.
Multi column
This section shares the practice I undertook with AI and automation before retreating towards community relations. In it I offer up some of these inquiries and outcomes of practice in a way to reflect on why I moved away from working with these technologies. This section also doesn't have a canvas, but shares the knowledge base practices that have made room for this research to emerge from. To do this it shares the materials for a workshop I ran with Batool Desouky called Making Sense With Obsidian.

info_showCustomIcons.description: Show custom icons for files and folders

info_showDefaultFolderIcons.description: Show a default icon of a folder for every folder in the tree

info_showDefaultFileIcons.description: Show a default icon of a file for every file in the tree

info_defaultFolderIcon.description: The icon to use for folders. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultFileIcon.description: The icon to use for files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultMediaIcon.description: The icon to use for media files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_exposeStartingPath.description: Whether or not to show the current file in the file tree when the page is first loaded

info_minCollapseDepth.description: Only allow outline items to be collapsed if they are at least this many levels deep in the tree.

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site
